name: ai: commandable
description: the game has AI companions that can be commanded by the player (fully or partially)

name: ai: uncommandable
description:
the game has AI companions that CANNOT be commanded by the player

includes all types of companions as long as it is not only an escort mission and the companion follows the player

name: auto: assemble
description:
automation is directly build/assembled, usually some kind of machine

something can only count as automation if it could also be done manually by the player in some other way, with the automation therefore replacing manual labor (preferably introducing a certain depth)

name: auto: configure
description:
automation is configured but not directly build/assembled

something can only count as automation if it could also be done manually by the player in some other way, with the automation therefore replacing manual labor (preferably introducing a certain depth)

name: character editor
description: the game has a character editor which allows the player to personalize the character they play to some degree (age, gender, name, class, race, ..)

name: chunk: continuous
description: there are no clear boundaries in the game world, there are seamless transitions between different game parts

name: chunk: package wise
description: there are clear boundaries in the game world, different game parts can be named (or even separately chosen to play again)

name: com: chat wheel
description:
players can post premade messages to a chat, usually by using a wheel where they can choose between a set of available messages

This acts as a barrier for toxicity and does not require devs to implement chat filters.

name: com: external
description: players communicate outside of the game, e.g. because they are in the same location or by using other software

name: com: free drawing
description: players can draw to communicate with other players, e.g. by drawing on a map to indicate where something is

name: com: free gestures
description: players can communicate via free gestures (most likely only VR games)

name: com: gestures
description: players can communicate using a set of predefined gestures their character can make

name: com: markers and pings
description: players can communicate through markers and pings, i.e., small symbolic representations

name: com: npc and npc
description: NPCs talk to each other (e.g. ambient dialog or cutscenes) which can act as a source of information for the player

name: com: npc and player
description: NPCs communicate with the player (not their in-game character), e.g. in a tutorial. This can include narrators.

name: com: npc and playercharacter
description: The players can communicate with NPCs via their in-game character, e.g. to gather information, complete quests, trade resources or just chat

name: com: proximity communication
description:
Communication is bound to a location, e.g. players can only hear each other when they are close to each other in the game world.
This is allowed to be tagged for single player games.

name: com: soundboard
description: players can communicate through a sound board, e.g., through a set of predefined spoken lines (voiced by someone else)

name: com: text chat
description: players can communicate through a text chat

name: com: voice chat
description: players can communicate through a voice chat

name: dd: arrow indicator
description: players are shown a direction through an arrow indicator to help them navigate

name: dd: compass
description: players can navigate with the help of a compass

name: dd: ingame path trail
description: directions are given through a path that is overlayed on the game world, e.g. to show players which way they must go

name: enact violence
description: players solve problems or progress by enacting violence like killing creatures and defeating enemies

name: exp: heterogeneous
description: players get a diverse game experience because the game activities are very different

name: exp: homogeneous
description: players get a more homogeneous game experience, the core game activities "feel" the same

name: game object personalization
description: players can personalize game objects, e.g., through naming, coloring or cosmetics (clothing, hair styles)

name: ginfo: dialog
description: players need to collect relevant information by talking to NPCs

name: ginfo: exploration
description: players need to gather information by investigating their environment in the hopes of finding something, e.g. new items, an NPCs to talk to, etc.

name: ginfo: lookup
description: players need to gather information by looking up information in the game (looking at letters, looking at the quest log) - this does not include *searching*

name: ginfo: remember self
description: players need to remember gathered information themselves, since the game does not track it

name: ginfo: scouting
description: players need to collect information by (repeatedly) investigating an area, e.g. to check that nothing is there or to get information on an enemy

name: ginfo: text search
description: players can search through information by specifying search terms

name: goc: critical failure
description: the game is over when the player fails critically, e.g. death, which resets to a previous point in the game, thereby losing any progress between this point and the critical failure

name: goc: none
description: there is no direct game over condition, e.g., because the game continues after the story ends (Minecraft) or because there was no end to begin with (endless mode)

name: goc: permadeath
description: When the player dies, the game resets to the start, as is common for rogue-like games. This does not include games where the player can simply load, that would just be a critical failure.

name: goc: reach endpoint
description: The game ends when a certain point is reached, e.g., the conclusion of the main quest. A game ending means that the game can not be played further without starting anew.

name: info: arrange
description: players can spatially arrange information

name: info: connect
description: players can (visually) connect pieces of information, e.g. via red strings like a graph

name: info: distribute
description: players must distribute information amongst themselves to tackle problems (multiplayer only)

name: info: mark/tag
description: players can tag information, which can be abstract or concrete, e.g. by tagging video clips based on their content

name: info: other
description: placeholder for any missing tags to organize information

name: info: record
description: players can record information themselves, e.g. with a text note

name: info: visibility
description:
players can (visually) hide information not relevant to the current problem, e.g. by clicking an item to reduce its rendering opacity

this does not include being able to show or hide information in windows, e.g. a quest log

name: int: highlight
description: visual highlights, e.g. for status changes, important entities, etc.

name: int: new data
description: the game communicates that new data is available to the player, e.g., a new quest, new log entry, new armor, etc.

name: int: visual aid
description: the game has visual aids (mostly for navigation) like ledges that are painted in a particular color to indicate that they can be climbed on

name: map: drawing
description: players can draw on a map

name: map: minimap
description: the game includes a minimap version of a larger map

name: map: path trail
description: path trails are shown on a map

name: map: place symbols
description: players can place symbols on the map, e.g. location markers

name: map: quicktravel
description:
players can use something (icon) on a map to quickly travel to other locations

NOTICE: A game feature is only quicktravel if the player could also travel the same distance in a slower way e.g. walking by foot vs clicking on the minimap.

name: map: symbols
description: the game includes a map (at all), usually with symbols that provide information on specific locations

name: mech: card game
description: The game has mechanics based around card games. This can be actual card games or just prominent elements of card games.

name: mech: challenges
description: the game has (optional) content intended to challenge players' skill, e.g. challenge dungeons

name: mech: change game speed
description: players can change the speed of the game, e.g., through slow motion/bullet time, by having a tactical pause or directly controling the speed (slower/faster)

name: mech: combos
description: the game has combos in some sense, e.g., when players successfully chain or combine (specific) attacks, when players can craft combos, etc.

name: mech: configurable quick access
description: The player can configure some type of quick access. This could be a hotbar or a radial menu where items/skills can be assigned.

name: mech: other
description: for any missing tags related to mechanics

name: mech: physical save points
description:
there are physical objects in the game where the player can save and/or rest, optionally with replenishing their health

saving can mean creating a new save file or getting a new checkpoint

name: mech: place & arrange
description: players can place and arrange objects inside the game world, usually employed for building or moving units

name: mech: predefined notes
description: the game provides information in the form of notes, audio diaries, encylopedias, letters, etc.

name: mech: quest tracker display
description: players can see their current quest objectives/tasks displayed on the screen (automatically or by setting a quest as active)

name: mech: queue
description: players can queue specific actions like movement or more complex commands; does not count if the game only internally uses a queue, it needs to be visually present or possible to see for the player

name: mech: quicktime events
description: the game contains events that require players to press a specific button in a given time window; can have bad consequences if failed

name: mech: skilltree & upgrades
description: the game includes systems, like a skill or research tree, where upgrades are successively unlocked by the player

name: mech: stealth
description: the game has stealth mechanics like sneaking, wearing disguises or stealing

name: mech: transform
description: players can transform things inside the game into other things, e.g. crafting (this does not including paying for things with money)

name: mech: vehicles & mounts
description: players can use vehicles or mounts (e.g., horses, dragons, etc.) to traverse the world: these must  1. have their own controls and 2. be an alternative way of moving. Should apply to almost everything where the player controls a vehicle or mount.

name: mini: busywork
description:
minigames that consist of busywork (see "busywork" tag), e.g. trivial and repetitive tasks

minigames are generally expected to be different from the main game - for example in terms of input/movement

name: mini: logic
description:
includes minigames that can primarily be solved by employing logic, e.g Towers of Hanoi

minigames are generally expected to be different from the main game - for example in terms of input/movement

name: mini: luck
description:
minigames that are luck based like flipping a coin

minigames are generally expected to be different from the main game - for example in terms of input/movement

name: mini: skill
description:
includes minigames that can primarily be solved through skill, e.g clicking objects in a short time frame in the correct order

minigames are generally expected to be different from the main game - for example in terms of input/movement

name: mini: strategy
description:
minigames that require the player to do some strategic thinking

minigames are generally expected to be different from the main game - for example in terms of input/movement

name: misc: collectibles
description: the game has collectible items that players can collect during gameplay and that are usually displayed in a gallery somewhere

name: misc: community content
description: the game allows for community content (e.g., via the steam workshop)

name: misc: difficulty settings
description: the game allows players to customize the difficulty by selecting a difficulty level or customized game settings that influence difficulty

name: misc: educational
description: The game includes educational content that directly aims to be educational. This does not include when information/architecture is based on the real-world but just part of the game as such. There must be obvious intent to educate.

name: misc: secrets
description: the game includes content that is hidden or not easily accessible, e.g. easter eggs, treasures, special endings ..

name: misc: tutorial
description: the game includes a tutorial of some kind (can be big or small)

name: mng: compose team
description:
players need to compose a team of units

requires that units influence each other e.g. in terms of interaction

name: mng: consumables
description: players need to manage consumable resources like money, materials, potions, etc.

name: mng: inventory
description: players need to manage their inventory , which is limited by space or weight (choose which items to keep)

name: mng: items
description: players need to manage which items they use, buy, equip, etc.

name: mng: skills
description: players need to manage skills, e.g., when to use a skill, when to upgrade it or which skills to equip

name: mng: time
description: players need to manage time, e.g., because the game has other systems based around time

name: mng: units
description: players need to manage mutliple units

name: mul: couch coop
description: (cooperative) multiplayer that is played in the same location, using a single device

name: mul: leave game objects
description: players can leave behind objects in the shared (multiplayer) world

name: mul: leave text
description: players can add (persistent) text to a shared (multiplayer) game world

name: mul: local multiplayer
description: multiplayer that is played in the same network (LAN), using multiple devices

name: mul: online multiplayer
description: multiplayer that is played online (using multiple devices)

name: ord: branches
description: game contents can be experienced/accessed in a branched order, i.e., there are different options but still some restrictions

name: ord: linear
description: game contents can only be experienced/accessed in a predetermined linear order

name: ord: open
description: game contents can be experienced/accessed in any order, e.g., in open-world games

name: pc: discovery
description: personal challenge based on discovery of new information about the story, game world, characters, etc.

name: pc: emotional challenges
description: personal challenge based on emotional reactions to story developments or other parts of the game

name: pc: labor or busywork
description: personal challenge based on simply having to do a lot of work

name: pc: logic challenges
description: personal challenge based on using logic to find correct solutions

name: pc: memory
description: personal challenge based on remembering vital information

name: pc: moral challenges
description: personal challenge based around the morality of events in the game

name: pc: other
description: any other unique challenges

name: pc: skill or dexterity
description: personal challenge based on mastering a skill (usually hand-eye coordination) to a certain degree

name: pc: strategy challenges
description: personal challenge based on problems of a strategic nature, e.g. players must manage resources and make plans to overcome challenges

name: rep: gameplay branches
description:
the game provides mechanics that result in different ways of playing the game (e.g. skilltree)

this does not apply to scenarios where the core gameplay is the same but with a slightly different flavor (e.g. pokemon)

name: rep: meta progression
description: players progress after finishing a game/match (e.g. increasing a character level in multiplayer games, etc.)

name: rep: narrative branches
description: players can make different choices for the narrative, resulting in different outcomes

name: rep: scoring system
description: game includes a scoring or ranking system that may motivate players to replay (sections of) the game

name: rep: unlock content
description: players unlock new content after finishing the game or a run of the game, e.g. new levels, new cosmetics, new game modes, story elements, etc.

name: res: apply logic
description: players must apply logic for problem-solving, e.g., for abstract puzzles

name: res: apply physics
description: problem solving involves systems and rules based on physics, e.g. jump-and-run or more complex puzzles

name: res: combine information
description: players need to combine gathered information, it's less about applying logic and more about trying to find (loose) connections

name: res: learn or apply language
description:
merge tags:
apply preknown language, body language, learn programming, learn unknown language

name: res: process of elimination
description: problem-solving is partially based on process of elimination

name: res: social deduction
description: players need to engage in social deduction for problem-solving

name: res: strategic planning
description: players must devise an appropriate strategy to solve problems, weighing different options and uncertainty

name: rnd: ability outcome
description: the outcome of an ability/skill is randomized to some degree

name: rnd: ability select
description: which abilities can be selected is randomized to some degree

name: rnd: agents
description: how (AI) agents are spawned or how they behave is randomized to some degree

name: rnd: enemies
description: how enemies are spawned or how they behave is randomized to some degree

name: rnd: events
description: random events can occur during gameplay (e.g. natural disasters or NPC quests)

name: rnd: loot
description: loot (items that enemies drop or that can be found in chests) is randomized to some degree, e.g., using a loot table

name: rnd: world generation
description: the game world is randomly generated to some degree, e.g., procedural generation

name: rpt: grinding
description:
players can progress by grinding, this is very similar to busywork since players continuously do the same activity, e.g. kill a specific enemy type.

can be motivated internally (players want to level-up) or because the game difficulty forces them to by not providing other means of progressing

name: rpt: practicing
description: players may want to practice to tackle a (skill) challenge or simply get better

name: rpt: trial and error
description:
players solve problems via trial and error since they can just try out different solution strategies without penalty (or with reloading)

NOTICE: only tag this when this is a viable strategy

name: sch: blueprint
description:
players can define or build blueprints that function as a planning help.
This can for example refer to a UI in which the player can plan what he wishes to do in the future.

name: sch: copy-paste
description: players can use copy-paste features for building for example selecting an area that is copied to another location.

name: sch: recipe
description:
the game includes recipes, e.g., for crafting
A recipe would contain a list of items that are required for crafting.

name: sch: template
description: players can define (building) templates to reuse at another point in time. For example when creating a building and saving it to be build a second time later on.

name: set-g: adventure
description: similar to adventure stories, where some venture is undertaken by the protagonist (think Indiana Jones, Tomb Raider, ..)

name: set-g: comedy & parody
description: the game has a comedic tone, not taking itself too seriously or explicitly aiming to be funny

name: set-g: crime & mystery
description: mystery stories, like detective fiction or crime thrillers

name: set-g: fantasy
description: contains many typical fantasy elements (magic, elves, dragons)

name: set-g: horror & gore
description: the story/gameplay features (psychological) horror and/or gore

name: set-g: post apocalypse
description: the story is set in a post-apocalypse (zombies, nuclear bomb, ecocide, ..)

name: set-g: science fiction
description: science fiction story that is usually set in a futurist scenario with evolved technology (space ships, FTL travel, ..)

name: set-g: space western
description: futuristic space settings meets western elements (e.g. space cowboys)

name: set-g: steampunk
description: setting inspired by the victorian era with a heavy focus on steam-based machines

name: set-g: western
description: contains typical western elements like cowboys, sheriffs, and 19th century architecture/technology

name: set-g: zombie apocalypse
description: set in an apocalypse caused by zombies

name: set-s: africa
description: game location is set in (fictional) africa

name: set-s: americas
description: game location is set in (fictional) north or south america

name: set-s: asia
description: game location is set in (fictional) asia

name: set-s: europe
description: game location is set in (fictional) europe

name: set-s: nature
description: game location is mostly in nature (so not around human settlements)

name: set-s: sea
description: game location is set at sea (can also be a ship)

name: set-s: space
description: game location is set in outer space

name: set-s: space ship
description: game is set on a space ship

name: set-s: underwater
description: game is largely set underwater

name: set-s: urban
description: game is set in urban areas (cities, villages)

name: set-t: antiquity
description: game is set in a (fictional) time from 800 b.c to 500

name: set-t: early modern age
description: game is set in a (fictional) time from 1500â€“1800, early modern period, between middle ages and modern period

name: set-t: futuristic
description: game is set in a (fictional) futuristic time

name: set-t: middle ages
description: game is set in a (fictional) time from 500 to 1500

name: set-t: modern times
description: game is set in a (fictional) modern times starting around the 20th century

name: sim: daily routines
description: agents in the game have simulated daily routines

name: sim: day-night cycle
description: the game includes a day/night cycle or meaningful connection of daytime to other game mechanics

name: sim: economy
description: the game features a simulated (even if simple) economy with supply and demand

name: sim: needs
description: the game simulates needs of people, animals, plants, etc.

name: sim: seasons & weather
description: the game simulates weather or seasons in some way meaningful to other game mechanics

name: spn: marker
description: the game provides markers in the game world to support spatial navigation

name: spn: object quicktravel
description: players can quicktravel using objects in the game world like portals, teleport scrolls, gates, etc.

name: spn: other
description: any other type of spatial navigation

name: spn: pings
description: players can support spatial navigation through pings (likely only multiplayer)

name: struc: cyclic
description: the game has a cyclic structure, i.e., it can (or should) be played multiple times for a good player experience

name: struc: match based
description:
the game is match-based, i.e., each play session consists of 1 or more matches that are clearly separated from each other

the most prominent examples can be found in multiplayer games (e.g. DotA 2 or Counter Strike)

name: struc: turnbased
description: (some) parts of the game are structured in a turn-based manner, usually related to combat

name: subversion: game mechanics
description: the game subverts known conventions around game mechanics

name: subversion: storytelling
description: the game subverts conventions around storytelling practices

name: top: aliens
description: the game tackles topics/issues related to aliens, be they friendly or hostile

name: top: art
description: the game tackles topics/issues related to art

name: top: colonialization
description: the game tackles topics/issues related to colonization

name: top: conquest
description: the game tackles topics/issues related to (violent) conquest

name: top: creatures
description: the game tackles topics/issues related to creatures, which are fantastical or otherworldly lifeforms that need not be hostile

name: top: discrimination
description: the game tackles topics/issues related to discrimination (racism, sexism, ..)

name: top: economy
description: the game tackles topics/issues related to the economy, e.g. how people are affected by it differently

name: top: ecosystems
description: the game tackles topics/issues related to ecosystems, e.g. how they work or how they can end up collapsing

name: top: family & friends
description: the game tackles topics/issues related to family and friendship

name: top: free will
description: the game tackles topics/issues related to free will

name: top: gods
description: the game tackles topics/issues related to gods, can be in the form of mythology or other

name: top: grief & loss
description: the game tackles topics/issues related to grief and loss

name: top: language
description: the game tackles topics/issues related to language, e.g. how we communicate with language and how that shapes culture

name: top: machine intelligence
description: the game tackles topics/issues related to machine intelligence

name: top: magic
description: the game tackles topics/issues related to magic and the supernatural

name: top: monsters
description: the game tackles topics/issues related to monsters, e.g. hostile creatures that aim to hurt people

name: top: music
description: the game tackles topics/issues related to music

name: top: other
description: for any missing topics, e.g. technology

name: top: parenthood
description: the game tackles topics/issues related to parenthood, be they from the parent's or the child's perspective

name: top: plants
description: the game tackles topics/issues related to plant life

name: top: power struggle
description: the game tackles topics/issues related to power struggles, e.g. between neighboring countries, families, etc.

name: top: religion
description: the game tackles topics/issues related to religion, e.g. spirituality and the workings of organized religion

name: top: romantic love
description: the game tackles topics/issues related to romantic love, e.g. falling in love, romantic relationships, etc.

name: top: sanity
description: the game tackles topics/issues related to sanity and mental health

name: top: settlement
description: the game tackles topics/issues related to founding/building/maintaining a settlement

name: top: sports
description: the game tackles topics/issues related to sports

name: top: synthetic life
description: the game tackles topics/issues related to synthetic life, usually created by people

name: top: time
description: the game tackles topics/issues related to time, e.g. when the player needs to achieve something in a specific amount of time, or when a groundhog day scenario is at play

name: top: violence
description: the game tackles topics/issues related to violence, e.g. why/how/when people inflict violence upon each other

name: top: war
description: the game tackles topics/issues related to war

name: ui: accessibility
description: UI settings for accessibility, e.g., a color-blind mode

name: ui: sandbox
description: UI sandbox that allows players to freely organize the layout

name: vis: bars
description: the game contains bar-based visualizations, e.g. health bars

name: vis: charts
description: the game contains charts (axes + data), e.g. a line chart showing number of slain enemies over time

name: vis: graphs
description: the game contains graph-like visualizations of data in the game, e.g. a skilltree

name: vis: icons & symbols
description: the game contains icons or symbols that encode game-relevant data (cannot be JUST interface elements)

name: vis: matrix & tables
description: the game contains matrix-like visualizations or tables of data

name: vis: other
description: all types of visualizations that do not fall into one of the other categories

name: vis: overlay
description: the game visualizes data through an overlay

name: vision: cones
description: vision works through cones (visible)

name: vision: fog of war
description:
game has fog of war, i.e., vision is limited to some area around players and other items/units/objects that give vision
this can include unexplored areas on a map being hidden

name: vision: other
description: game includes some other form of vision model

name: wyd: building
description: the player does a lot of building, e.g. a city, machines, etc.

name: wyd: crafting
description: the player does a lot of crating, e.g weapons, potions, spells, furniture, meals, etc.

name: wyd: detective work
description: the player does activities related to detective work, e.g. talking to witnesses, gathering evidence, connecting pieces of information, etc.

name: wyd: exploring
description: the player does a lot of exploring of the game (world)

name: wyd: farming
description: the player does a lot of farming, e.g. buying and sowing crops, watering them and harvesting

name: wyd: fighting
description: the player does a lot of fighting, be it melee or ranged, against some type of enemy

name: wyd: managing
description: the player does a lot of managing, e.g. hiring and firing employees, starting machines, buying supplies, ordering units around, etc.

name: wyd: platforming
description: the player does a lot of platforming, e.g. jumping between platforms

name: wyd: puzzling
description: the player does a lot of puzzling, e.g. they need to solve logic riddles

name: wyd: racing
description: the player does a lot of racing with some kind of vehicle/mount
